reasoning: Cruciality is high because the paper’s practical upshot (how much to prioritise survival/avoid-downside vs steering/seek-upside) can change substantially depending on intertheoretic comparison/normalisation; resolving it could plausibly redirect strategy. Paper-specificity is high since it directly targets the paper’s Section 3.5 discussion of range/variance/pairwise normalisations and their ability to reverse rankings. Tractability is moderate: you can make progress by (i) formal analysis of desiderata/axioms for intertheoretic comparisons and (ii) robustness studies over modeled option sets, but the core “defensible enough” dispute is partly irreducibly philosophical. Clarity is decent but not perfect: ‘defensible enough’ and ‘realistic option sets’ are underspecified, and two questions are bundled (normative selection + empirical/quantitative flip-frequency). Decision hook is strong: it explicitly connects answers to flipping priority between survival-focused and upside/steering-focused strategies. Dead weight is low; most text sharpens motivation and ties to the paper, though some restatement is not strictly necessary.
title: Robustness of moral aggregation methods to survival versus upside tradeoffs
